p: Catalonia, in the northeast of Spain has one of the highest rates of new HIV diagnoses in the country. In 2017, a total of 578 new diagnoses were reported, that is, 8.1 per 100,000 persons [ 19], which is higher than the European Union median (6.4 cases per 100,000 population) [ 20]. Men account for 86% of cases. Half of the diagnoses reported were in GBMSM (54%). Of these, 47% were diagnosed in people born outside Spain. More than half (58%) of all new diagnoses were made in the city of Barcelona. The median age of the cases was 36 years. Of all new HIV diagnoses in 2017, 38% were aged 30–39 years, 29% were ≥ 40 years, and 33% were under 30 years [ 19]. In Spain, studies on the effect of the geographical and socioeconomic context in the distribution of new HIV diagnoses are lacking.
